Given a goal and 2 solutions, choose the most appropriate solution.
Goal: How to clean wall clock battery Terminals?
- Solution 1: Take down the clock from wall and remove the batteries. Use a damp soft cotton swab to remove any major corrosion deposits. Wear vinyl gloves while cleaning any battery corrosion. Make your cleaning agent by combine 1 tablespoon of baking soda with a teaspoon or so of water. Stir to make a paste. Apply the baking soda paste to the battery connections using a cotton swab or small piece of cloth. Once the baking soda is applied, you may see it bubble and foam, as it reacts with the corrosion. When the foaming stops and there are no major deposits left to be scraped out. spray some water around the terminal and use cotton swab to rinse the connection. Wipe the terminals clean with a dry clean rag. Add something hydrophobic, such as petroleum jelly or grease to the now cleaned terminals. This will help slow future corrosion. Put new batteries into the now clean battery cradle, and close up the case or put back on the cover.
- Solution 2: Take down the clock from wall and remove the batteries. Use a damp soft cotton swab to remove any major corrosion deposits. Wear vinyl gloves while cleaning any battery corrosion. Make your cleaning agent by combine 1 tablespoon of baking soda with a teaspoon or so of water. Stir to make a paste. Apply the baking soda paste to the battery connections using a cotton swab or small piece of cloth. Once the baking soda is applied, you may see it bubble and foam, as it reacts with the corrosion. When the foaming stops and there are no major deposits left to be scraped out. Rinse the connections by using just a little water applied with a cotton swab. Be very careful not to get any water any electrical components. Wipe the terminals clean with a dry clean rag. Add some petroleum jelly to the cleaned terminals. Put new batteries into the now clean battery cradle, and close up the case or put back on the cover.

Answer by returning either Solution 1 or Solution 2

Make peach cobbler in a jar 6 cups peaches, peeled and chopped    2 tbsp tapioca starch, or 1 1/2 tbsp cornstarch    2 tbsp honey    1 inch knob of ginger, finely grated    2 tbsp lemon juice    CRISP TOPPING    1 cup oat flour (grind rolled oats, use gluten-free oats if necessary)    11/2 cups rolled oats (not quick oats)    1/2 cup chopped almonds (optional)    1/2 cup brown sugar or coconut palm sugar    1/2 cup melted butter    pinch of salt        Report this ad         INSTRUCTIONS    Preheat oven to 375°F.    Peel peaches, remove stone, slice and chop.    In a large bowl, toss with tapioca starch, honey, ginger and lemon juice. - Solution 1: Grease the pan with a non-stick spray. Grease the back of a large, non-slotted serving spoon. - Solution 2: Grease the pan with spray. Grease a small, slotted serving spoon. Pour the cooled cereal-marshmallow mix into the greased pan, using the greased spoon to get all of the mixture out of the pan. Use the back of the greased spoon to slowly and carefully press the cereal mixture into the pan. Slide the spoon over the cold cereal, pressing gently, more toward the middle than the sides. Dip the spoon in more oil to re-grease it as needed.

Solution 1

Solution 1: CHAIN STITCH        Hold crochet hook in right hand and make a slip knot on hook.        Bring yarn over hook from back to front and grab it with hook.z        Draw hooked yarn through slip knot and onto hook. This makes one chain stitch.        Repeat Steps 2 and 3 until you have the desired number of stitches. One loop will remain on hook.            SINGLE CROCHET        Skip the first chain stitch.        Insert hook into center of next chain stitch. Draw yarn through the chain stitch and up onto the hook. There are now 2 loops on hook.        Bring yarn over hook from back to front, and draw it through both loops on hook. One loop remains on the hook, and you have just made one single crochet stitch.        Repeat Steps 2 and 3 in each of the remaining chains—be sure to work in the very last chain. You have now completed one row of single crochet. At the end of the row, make one chain stitch, then turn the work counter-clockwise, leaving the hook in the chain.        Now you begin another row, working into the stitches of the previous row. Make one single crochet stitch in first stitch and in each remaining stitch of the previous row. Be sure to work into the last stitch. Chain 1, turn.        Repeat single crochet rows following the pattern.

Solution 1: Hydra are related to jellyfish and are a common pest in home aquariums. Hydra are not generally harmful to fish, except they do have the ability to catch and consume small fry and shrimplets. Hydra are usually an indication of overfeeding, so feeding smaller quantities less often will help put a dent in their populations but their populations can be knocked out completely with a dose of common dog dewormer, available over the counter called Fenbendazole. Dose 0.1g fenbendazole per 10g of water volume. For heavy infestations, monitor water quality carefully after treatment to monitor for harmful ammonia spikes from decaying hydra.

Given a goal and 2 solutions, choose the most appropriate solution.
Goal: How to sew a straight stitch for mending a pillowcase seam by hand?
- Solution 1: Thread the needle using a wire threader, to save many minutes. Once the thread is through, double it back for strength, tie a knot at the end, leaving the thread twice as long as the pillow case. That way you won't have to stop in the middle and thread a new needle. Turn the pillow case inside out, and begin at the edge closest to you. Pierce the fabric, sending the needle away from you, and bring it back out 1/8th of an inch further, in and out, each time. Repeat until the entire edge has been re-seamed. Tie a knot at the end of the pillowcase so it won't unravel in your sleep. Turn the pillow case right side out, and voila your seam will be repaired.
- Solution 2: Gather the pillow case edge by edge and fold it over so the rip doesn't show, or use a dark colored dye to conceal it. If the pillow case is now too small, you can shorten the pillow a bit so it will still fit.

Answer by returning either Solution 1 or Solution 2
Solution 1

Given a goal and 2 solutions, choose the most appropriate solution.
Goal: How often should I water my apple tree?
- Solution 1: If the tree is one or two years old, give it a really deep watering twice a week, or less often if the rain is plentiful in your area. After a fruit tree is 3 + years old water only when the soil is dry to 8 inches or so. When the tree is just establishing itself, deep watering promotes deep roots and shallow watering promotes shallow roots, a liability for a tree.
- Solution 2: Apple trees don't need to be watered at all unless you live in a complete desert. Let mother nature take care of it.

Answer by returning either Solution 1 or Solution 2
Solution 1

Goal: Is genetically modifying DNA the same as what breeders and horiculturalists have been doing for centuries?
- Solution 1: Genetically modifying an organism is no different than what horticulturalists and breeders have been doing for centuries. Breeding pigs with pigs and crossing plant types uses the natural functions of biologic systems, and requires no forced introduction of foreign genetic material from one organism into another organism, unless forced to do so by government regulations which makes it totally safe.
- Solution 2: Genetically modifying an organism is completely different. The DNA of an organism has a protection against being modified by another invading organism, so the introduction of another specie's genetic material must be forced and is a crude unpredictable process at the current time. There is no prediction of what such disruptions will cause in future generations of the organism that reproduces with compromised DNA.

Solution 2

Put all ingredients into a pot, bring to a boil stirring occasionally. When mixture comes to a boil, reduce heat to medium and let boil for 10 minutes. Then remove from heat allow to cool for 5 minutes, then either put in a blender or food processor (I used a food processor) and process until it is smooth in consistency (about 1 minute.)    Then put in a container and serve. Refrigerate for storage. Lasts 4 weeks in the fridge in an airtight container.Whisk vinegar, sugar, and salt in a small bowl until sugar and salt are dissolved.
